title: 106_hr3765
content: The "Health Insurance Liability Recovery Protection Act of 2000" is also known as the Health Insurance Liability Recovery Protection Act. It includes provisions for patient protection in case of third-party recoveries under group health plans. This Act amends the Public Health Service Act to establish standards relating to patient protection in such cases. The Health Insurance Liability Recovery Protection Act of 2000 prohibits group health plans from recovering more than the amounts spent on behalf of participants from settlements or judgments. Group health plans must comply with notice requirements similar to those under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. SEC. 714. Standard relating to patient protection in case of third party recoveries. SEC. 714. Standard relating to patient protection in case of third party recoveries. A group health plan or health insurance issuer cannot recover more than the amounts spent on behalf of a participant or beneficiary from settlements or judgments. This requirement is considered a material modification in the plan terms, with notice required within 60 days of the first plan year it applies. Section 732(a) of the Act is amended to include sections 711 and 714. The table of contents is also updated to reflect the new item related to section 713. Section 714 of the Act introduces a standard for patient protection in case of third party recoveries. This amendment is reflected in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment introduces a standard for patient protection in case of third party recoveries, limiting the amount a group health plan can recover from a participant or beneficiary to the amounts expended on their behalf. The amendment extends patient protection standards to individual health insurance coverage in the same way as group health plans, with notice requirements similar to group health plans. Effective dates apply to group health plans starting January 1, 2001. The amendment extends patient protection standards to individual health insurance coverage starting January 1, 2001, with exceptions for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements. The Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services will coordinate administration through an interagency memorandum of understanding. The Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services will coordinate enforcement of patient protection standards to avoid duplication of efforts and assign priorities in enforcement.
